pr_title: [Microservice] Route Manager Refactor to Support Neutron Routers

timeline.bodyText:
@xieus Do we need admin_state_up attribute for VPC router?
'admin_state_up' is for neutron router actually. If we don't need it in VPC, we can put this attribute in the neutron specific attribute object which is router_extra_attributes object.
timeline.author: cj-chung
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,100 @@
+/*
+Copyright 2019 The Alcor Authors.
+
+Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License");
+        you may not use this file except in compliance with the License.
+        You may obtain a copy of the License at

+        distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS,
+        WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied.
+        See the License for the specific language governing permissions and
+        limitations under the License.
+*/
+package com.futurewei.alcor.web.entity.route;
+
+import com.fasterxml.jackson.annotation.JsonProperty;
+import com.futurewei.alcor.common.entity.CustomerResource;
+import lombok.Data;
+import org.springframework.data.annotation.CreatedDate;
+import org.springframework.data.annotation.LastModifiedDate;
+
+import java.util.List;
+
+@Data
+public class NeutronRouterWebRequestObject extends CustomerResource {
+
+    @JsonProperty("routetable")
+    private RouteTable routeTable;
+
+    // store vpc_id
+    @JsonProperty("owner")
+    private String owner;
+
+    // store subnet_gateway_port_id / interface
+    @JsonProperty("ports")
+    private List<String> ports;
+
+    @JsonProperty("tenant_id")
+    private String tenantId;
+
+    @JsonProperty("admin_state_up")

replies.bodyText:
This depends on whether users could leverage this field in the VPC scenario, and how we plan to use this field.
The answer to the first question could be NO as user may not have visibility to a VPC router.
For the second question, can admin use this field to check L3 routing status or something else?
replies.author: xieus

replies.bodyText: For VPC, I think the router is implicit for user, even for the admin, since one VPC can only has one router. So, admin_state or router_state for VPC is meaningless. In VPC's L3 routing, most of operations are depends on routing tables, but in Neutron's case, they are depends on router.
replies.author: cj-chung

replies.bodyText: Combined the fields in one class could make our model cover both vpc and neutron router,  if there is no other effect
replies.author: kevin-zhonghao

timeline.bodyText: @kevin-zhonghao There are multiple routetables for a router. It's better rename 'routetable' to 'routetables'
timeline.author: cj-chung

replies.bodyText: Actually our vpc and subnet still use the previous APIs of route manager, is that correct?
replies.author: kevin-zhonghao

replies.bodyText: 'routetable' to 'routetables' issue has been fixed
replies.author: kevin-zhonghao

timeline.bodyText: @kevin-zhonghao @xieus Again, we need to think about the usage of this attribute 'admin_state_up'. It's for Neutron router only, not for VPC router. Should we put this attribute in the 'router_extra_attribute'?
timeline.author: cj-chung

replies.bodyText: does it hurt anything if we always assume the admin_state_up=true? In ACA, we don't have admin_state_up concept today so it is assume true.
replies.author: er1cthe0ne

timeline.bodyText: @kevin-zhonghao Please make sure this call will handle atomically routing rule updating.
timeline.author: cj-chung

replies.bodyText: Got it
replies.author: kevin-zhonghao

timeline.bodyText: @kevin-zhonghao If there are gateway ports for subnets still in this router, the deletion should return error message to user.
timeline.author: cj-chung

replies.bodyText: left the comment for future already
replies.author: kevin-zhonghao

timeline.bodyText: @kevin-zhonghao We need to maintain the mapping for new added port and it's subnet in the Route Manager, did you maintain this mapping in this function?
timeline.author: cj-chung

replies.bodyText: I could modify this in the next PR as we talked about
replies.author: kevin-zhonghao

timeline.bodyText:
@kevin-zhonghao After successfully attached interface to router, we also need to return all connected subnet-ids to Port Manager. The algorithm as follow:

get ports array from the router.
get subnet-ids from the mapping table of port-subnet for all ports.
call Port Manager's /project/{project_id}/update-l3-neighbors/{new_subnet_id} with BODY {operation_type, vpcid, [old_subnet_ids]}.
timeline.author: cj-chung

replies.bodyText: @kevin-zhonghao BTW, we need to check if there is only one gateway port exists in the current router, we don't need to request PM for update-l3-neighbors. This operation only happen when there are more than 2 ports exist in the router.
replies.author: cj-chung

replies.bodyText: Got it ~ have marked already
replies.author: kevin-zhonghao

timeline.bodyText: @kevin-zhonghao We also need to update the port-subnet mapping table in the Route Manager.
timeline.author: cj-chung

replies.bodyText: leave it for next PR
replies.author: kevin-zhonghao

timeline.bodyText: @kevin-zhonghao Here has two for-loops for matching rules, it takes O(n^2). Do we have better algorithm reducing it to linear time O(n)? Such as using destination as index or key for RouteEntry.
timeline.author: cj-chung

replies.bodyText: If we use destination as index or key for RouteEntry, we may not guarantee the uniqueness of the RouteEntry key. Although here is two for-loops, but one of the n depends on requestbody, so the time complexity should be O(m * n), and m may not be very large, right?
replies.author: kevin-zhonghao

replies.bodyText: Agree. we can leave current design and implementation for now. We can wait until it hits performance issue when we doing perf-test.
replies.author: cj-chung

timeline.bodyText: @kevin-zhonghao we need to add a function call here for l3-neighbors-updating. It should be the function call to PM same as the previous one /project/{project_id}/update-l3-neighbors/{new_subnet_id}, but the detail contract is not confirm yet.  We can wait until the contract is confirmed.
timeline.author: cj-chung

replies.bodyText: Sure ~ left the comments already
replies.author: kevin-zhonghao

timeline.bodyText: @kevin-zhonghao Reserve the place to call PM for routing rule updating.
timeline.author: cj-chung

replies.bodyText: Sure
replies.author: kevin-zhonghao

timeline.bodyText: @kevin-zhonghao We need to maintain subnet-port mapping in Route Manager instead of query the mapping from Subnet Manager.
timeline.author: cj-chung

replies.bodyText: okay ~ left the TODO comments for next PR
replies.author: kevin-zhonghao

timeline.bodyText: @kevin-zhonghao Does this router contains routing rules?
timeline.author: cj-chung

replies.bodyText: Yes
replies.author: kevin-zhonghao

timeline.bodyText:
@kevin-zhonghao For VPC, it's simpler than Neutron. We just need to do the following tasks:

get router by VPC:id
get routetables from the router
get subnet-ids from each routetable
return all subnet-ids and router info
timeline.author: cj-chung

timeline.bodyText: Really like the comprehensive set of tests in this file 💯
timeline.author: xieus

timeline.bodyText: @kevin-zhonghao maybe it is time to start thinking about a generic validator for all microservices.
timeline.author: xieus

replies.bodyText: Yes I think so
replies.author: kevin-zhonghao

replies.bodyText: we could put all validator of microservices into one Util class
replies.author: kevin-zhonghao

replies.bodyText:
Correct. @kevin-zhonghao
That is one way - putting all the util methods together in a utii class, and those methods are set as static methods.
Alternative is to use OOD for validator - a base validator class defining the validate() interface, and a few more child classes inheriting from the base and implement the actual validate method.
Each child class is responsible of one specific class that it wants to validate.
replies.author: xieus

replies.bodyText: Yes ~ could we do this in next PR?
replies.author: kevin-zhonghao

replies.bodyText:
@kevin-zhonghao This is not urgent. Instead, we will need design the validator for the ground up and apply it to the web layers of all microservices (of course, starting with small, e.g., from vpc mgr).
Tracking the item in an issue #374 and assign to you and me :-)

timeline.bodyText:
Why you need to set routerID when routerExtraAttribute != null?
The routerID should be set when the router has or has not extra attribute.
timeline.author: cj-chung

replies.bodyText: The ID of NeutronRouterWebRequestObject should be router_id, but I used the BeanUtils.copyProperties method twice. The first time I used it, NeutronRouterWebRequestObject_id = router_id; But the second time I used it, route_extra_attribute_id would overwrite the previous value, so I had to change it set back
replies.author: kevin-zhonghao

timeline.message: Update design documents and table of content
Start docs for comm and controller
Rename fast path file and start feature comparison
update rescue path needed change table
Finalize review section in data store
Add one item for node monitoring
Reorganize monitoring doc and update design doc metadata format
Add API workflow chart for creation of vpc, subnet and port
added - Reference: Neutron High Level Flow
Update ToC with microservice doc link
Update ToC and add vpc/mac manager design files
Merge mac manager design spec from eunju:feature/macmanager
Add references for OpenStack and Alcor
